The immersive graphics and rich lore draw you in, while the diverse factions offer unique gameplay and endless replayability. The campaign is engaging, with challenging battles that keep you hooked. 185829956.review: This game will go down in history as the best Total War game and greatest achievement by Creative Assembly. It is a shining beacon of hope for anyone who questions whether an existing IP can be correctly and lovingly rendered into a video game. Everything about Warhammer II was as close to perfect as anyone could hope for. It improved on virtually every part of the Total War formula, stayed true to the lore and world of Warhammer, and consistently delivered excellent DLC and expansions that were, to 99.9% of fans, always worth every penny. The only downside is that the game set expectations its sequel could not meet, which is less a criticism of Warhammer II and more an indictment of Creative Assembly losing focus and falling out-of-touch with their players.

185682658.review:
Awesome game. 

It took me several re-installs before i could appreciate this game. The difficulty settings MUST be right for you, otherwise many of the well designed mechanics will seem arbitrary, so experiment with it. The experience also varies widely based on the faction/legendary lord that you choose and their starting location. Many play with Tyrion for their first campaign but this can make the game feel easy because his faction has 50% reduced upkeep on base units, taking pressure off your treasury, and he is surrounded by high elves who can form alliances and trade early. Most factions are not like this.

185682197.review:
If you didn't play this game by now, it's because you had to buy it only to unlock immortal empires in WH3, and now you are thinking play- or not to play?
The answer is both yes and no:

NO= if you are interested into mortal empires campaign then don't bother, much smaller version of WH3 IE with non polished factions and old mechanics with not as good graphics as you got used to.

YES= If you have disc space to go around install it, it doesn't hurt, and graphics are really not bad (I was actually surprised how good this game looks like, only problem was very bright UI, but that's minor issue).
And finally MAIN REASON to play it is Vortex campaign. Starting positions of factions are often different then in WH3, which makes it interesting, story is good, and there are nice shorts for your progress made for every race. I found Skaven gameplay especially interesting in this game.

If you already posses this game because of WH3, GIVE IT A TRY AT LEAST ONCE. Vortex is way better then Realms of Chaos imo, and it will also make you appriciate WH3 more when you see how much game mechanics are now better then in previous games.

185497532.review:
Total War: Warhammer 2 is a game that stands out in the realm of strategy games. With its rich lore, diverse factions, and intricate gameplay mechanics, it offers an unparalleled experience for both veterans and newcomers to the series.

Gameplay and Mechanics: The game excels in its blend of turn-based strategy and real-time battles. Each faction has its own unique units, abilities, and playstyles, ensuring that no two campaigns feel the same. The addition of the Vortex campaign adds a layer of urgency and excitement, as players race to control the Great Vortex and achieve their faction's ultimate goal.

Campaign: The campaign is where Total War: Warhammer 2 truly shines. The narrative is engaging, with each faction having its own story and objectives. The map is vast and beautifully designed, with a variety of terrains and environments that add depth to the strategic gameplay. The diplomacy system is also well-developed, allowing for complex alliances and rivalries.

Graphics and Sound: Visually, the game is stunning. The attention to detail in the unit designs and environments is impressive, and the battles are a spectacle to behold. The sound design complements the visuals perfectly, with epic music and sound effects that enhance the immersion.

Replayability: One of the game's greatest strengths is its replayability. With multiple factions to choose from, each with its own unique campaign, there is always something new to discover. The modding community also adds to the game's longevity, with a wealth of user-created content that keeps the game fresh and exciting.

Pros:

Diverse and unique factions with distinct playstyles.

Engaging and immersive campaign with rich lore.

Stunning graphics and sound design.

High replayability with multiple factions and modding support.

Cons:

The learning curve can be steep for new players.

Some performance issues on lower-end systems.

The complexity of the game may be overwhelming for casual players.

Conclusion: In conclusion, Total War: Warhammer 2 is a masterpiece of strategy gaming. Its combination of deep strategic gameplay, rich narrative, and stunning visuals makes it a must-play for any fan of the genre. Whether you're a seasoned veteran or a newcomer to the series, this game offers an experience that is both challenging and rewarding. Highly recommended!

185269894.review:
This is the slop that Creative Assembly serves up these days. Easily gobbled up by the modern smooth brained consumer. The very essence of what made Total War games great is gone now, replaced with; flashy animations, DLC that itches that scratch of the modern ADHD riddled audience and gameplay that consists of going woah as you watch a mammoth fight a medieval knight.

The limitations of history are what made it great. Artistic freedom has its merits, but if you give a giraffe a short neck, well it's no longer a giraffe. The beauty was in the real history, someone's dreams will never be more glorious or interesting than that. The strategy that came from the slight differences in the culture of the units and the play style of real historical warfare techniques. Battles that consisted of hammer and anvil strikes, kiting, pincer movements and using routing to drive your enemy off the battle field. The games were difficult in their own way, organically, especially to the average player.

Now these fantasy games are just about consuming. Appeasing the modern audience member, someone that collects figurines and claps at the end of superhero movies. They are just flashy trash. Magic cool downs, single entity units, blobs of units, essentially no routing (apart from dumb faction specific mechanics), I could go on.

On top of all that, what substance does the game actually have? no naval battles, the sieges are awful and the battles last 5 minutes. The games have went backwards mechanically and became dumber. But, they are now making games for an audience that doesn't complain and has no taste, enjoy your slop!

185247598.review:
It's a good game, 65 hours in i've yet to win a campaign [I've only played as Lord Skrolk 99% of the time]
This game actually forces me to use my brain, learning and implementing tactics, trial and error on which way is the fastest method to develop and which armies would counterattack the nearby factions. 
Unlike a lot of the total war games i've played, the biggest game changer here is magic.
If you can develop magic, implement it with strategies on how to move your army, position them etc. it will change the tides of a battle. 
If i dont stop writing here i might just write a lengthy essay about my experience and the best ways i've found to develop and win battles, so read no more aND JOIN THE VERMINTIDE! SKREEEEEEEEE

"You must be online to..." Yeah buddy, I have already played 400 hours of Warhammer 2. Then suddenly, you consider me "not online" and/or started requiring me to "be online". Towards what? Warhammer 1 & 2 suddenly stopped working for me. I was plyaing Warhammer 2 Mortal Empires, which requires Warhammer 1. This is the only reason I bought Warhammer 1. But with about 400 hours in Warhammer 2, suddenly I am unable to load existing Mortal Empires campaign. So I tried repairing Warhammer 2, then reinstalled Warhammer 1 to try and force it to recognize that I own Warhammer 1 as well.

There is absolutely no reason for such crap to take place. I have found other recent posts and reviews talking about the same issue. Do not under any circumstance buy this crap.

Update:
While the link from Steam to "Sega support" takes you to "sega.com" (as in not to an actual support page), I did manage to find where you create a sega account so you could theoretically create a support request (https://support.sega.com/hc/en-us/requests). It just so happens that this part is not working. When you click Submit, the page with your request is reloaded. If you then navigate to "My activities", you have no requests.

I also requested a refund from Steam. They say they only refund up to 2 weeks after making a purchase and closed my request. Picture it.  1200+ gold tier elven archers lined up, drawing a beady sight on an enemy lord.  Thousands of arrows rain down around him, but physics doesn't care. Finally you start sacrificing archers units; those units die too  Finally, the the last of your archers run out of ammo; now it's their turn.  Congrats, you're 4 hours into a campaign and you an your elite army been killed by a single lord who has a slightly dented health bar. 

Game is just as trash as the real thing.  Very pretty though.

184722751.review:
**Total War: Warhammer II - A Thrilling Fantasy Epic**

I've poured 22 hours into Total War: Warhammer II, and I can confidently say it's one of the most captivating strategy games I've ever played. The game masterfully blends epic real-time battles with intricate turn-based campaign management, creating an immersive and addictive experience.

The Warhammer world is brought to life with stunning visuals and a diverse roster of factions, each with unique units, mechanics, and playstyles. Whether you're commanding the High Elves, the Lizardmen, the Dark Elves, or the Skaven, you'll find a faction that resonates with your strategic preferences.

The battles are nothing short of spectacular. Commanding vast armies of infantry, cavalry, monsters, and magical creatures is a thrilling experience. The tactical depth is immense, requiring careful planning and execution to achieve victory.

The campaign map is equally impressive, offering a vast sandbox to explore and conquer. Managing your empire, forging alliances, and engaging in diplomacy are crucial to your success. The campaign objectives are varied and challenging, ensuring hours of engaging gameplay.

Total War: Warhammer II is a must-play for fans of strategy games and the Warhammer universe. It's a game that will consume your free time and leave you wanting more.

184675145.review: Jogo excelente, cada facção tem seus detalhes, rende várias horas facilmente.

184597287.review:
I've played one campaign, normal difficulty.  I won.  Apparently that took 46 hours of my life, for 160 turns.

Admittedly I did leave the computer running while I attended to things like 'having a life', but a lot of the play time was just watching the computer animate the turns of all of its sock-puppets.  Could the devs not default the computer-owned factions to 'fastest' animation?  It took me until turn 148 to work out that I could speed this turgid nonsense up.

If you've played Total War before, this game doesn't offer a lot of new challenges.  The battles are fundamentally different due to all the new mechanics (flying, magic, heroes) but most single-player Total War is won on the economy with only having to play battles where the auto button won't give a fair result (mostly defenses where you can obviously win but the auto is claiming you might lose).  Out of the maybe 20 hours of actual playtime it took me to win my first go (not all of the time watching the computer move pieces around), about 6 hours were defending the same defensive fortification against the same two computer opponents that were somehow able to keep generating full stacks of opponents that would apparently take the position easily if I just auto-ed it... so I had to keep playing that battle manually every time, winning comfortably, but it took about 15 minutes each time.

So yeah... I probably got to actually "play" the game for 14 hours, with the rest of the clock being taken up with repetitious animation and repetitious battles that are totally unnecessary, except for the AI being coded to tell you that your troops can't defend unless you babysit them.  The big set-piece "Chaos Invasion" thing was a let down - I'd built reasonable defenses after the first incursion showed up, so I proactively engaged with it and defeated it one turn without ever seeing any of the animation (targeted the boss dude with some resources, pressed auto, whole darn Chaos Invasion evaporated without me ever seeing a single sprite).

There were some nice elements - I played as "the Empire", and there's a plotline for you to follow (albeit it's a total railroad - either do the quests or don't, there aren't any choices involved).  But I enjoyed those set-piece battles.  The rest was a waste of money and time.

184324121.review:
Overall a great game.

Starting a campaign as a Skaven:
You recruit more rats,
burn down a elf city. after that a elf pays you 700 gold. In return they burn down one of your villages and head towards your capital,
you make your way towards the capital almost arriving,
the elves decide to attack you.
The game tells you that you will suffer an decisive defeat.
You choose to fight the battle, and use a doom wheel to distract most of the elves.
The elves abandon their leader to attack the wheel.
You send your rats out of the trees and swarm their leader, eventually wounding him. After a while the elves retreat and you win the battle.
After that you're giving the choice on what you want to do with the prisoners. You eat the prisoners. After that you chase down and attack the elves that retreated, while still being near your capital. You use the help of reinforcements to auto-resolve the battle, completely destroying the army of elves. You're then given the choice on what to do with the prisoners. You have no point in eating the prisoners, because you lost barely any troops. You still decide to eat the prisoners.

184015694.review: The first grand strategy game I've actually sat down and played thoroughly for at least one full campaign (maybe Alpha Centauri was the first actually, :shrug:). Verdict? A blast. I played the High Elves and the grand adventure to conquer most of the map got me "one more turn"ing quite a few late nights. I enjoyed the grand strategy aspects, it was approachable and not too complicated on the medium difficulty. The battles themselves, naturally, were a blast. After researching online about recommended troop combinations and battlefield formations/tactics it actually felt like I was a competent strategist (lol) - even able to eke out situations that I wouldn't have imagined were possible. Having only played one faction I haven't even begun to scratch the surface, but this definitely satisfied an itch I've had for diving into the grand strategy genre more deeply.

I love the fact that you can fight battles manually if you feel like some RTS , you can autoresolve every battle ([i]except main quest battles[/i]) and have a game much like Sid Meier's Civilization, but in a warhammer old world setting. 

I'm not a huge fan of paying a lot of money for DLC in games, but the fact it's tied to Warhammer III as well made me much more comfortable buying DLC when on sale.

183894260.review: Better than TWWH1 in every way. More races, more units, expanded campaign mechanics, etc. Combines with the first game for the Mortal Empires game mode which provides a ton of replayability. Multiple FLC releases. For those looking for a great fantasy strategy game that will consume you, this is it. Added bonus - combines with TWWH3 for Immortal Empires. Still worth playing TWWH2 for the Vortex campaign which I enjoyed immensely. Highly recommended!

183756088.review:
I regret buying this game. I didn't understand the DLC/monetization shift that the publisher had made, and it is malignant.

Valve should not allow this to occur on Steam: if you have reviews for a set of features, then the same title and art and description should not be allowed for a skeletonized version of those features at a lower price point, which then requires you to shell out $$$ in order to recover the features that were part of the original review experience.

183719990.review: As a newb I got kicked around like a football in battle. Custom battle mode is very very difficult. My solution was to get an Ai controlled second faction on my side, with the opponents also having a similar faction to help them. I chose dwarves and just had one Lord with maxed out standard cheap dwarf axe and shield warriors with 2 units of specials, and edited my allied Ai helper army to have ALL special monsters and four dryad units with the remainder spent on their upgrades. They provide the units that can resist the enemies special attacks while my own dwarves provide a wolfpack. It works, and I'm happy to just win.

183579146.review:
This is more of an massive DLC bundle for the first game than a complete stand alone title. The basic grand single player campaign is essentially the first game with DLC factions added. The story campaign is well done and worth a play as well. Since I tend to focus on the grand campaign, the sense that this is more of a DLC than new title is stronger. 
Some new mechanics breathe life into factions from the first game, for better or worse. While new factions get shiny new mechanics to work with, also for better or worse. For example the Dwarf Book of Grudges adds flavor to that faction, but can also feel like it has too much impact and limits your play style choices. As usual things like Auto-Resolve for battles is unbalanced at best. Now there is a preview of the outcome before choosing auto-resolve but even a battle the AI would hand you a decisive defeat are easily won by fighting the battle manually. 
There seems to be more diplomacy options but the AI still creates huge confederacies while you struggle to get trade agreements with friendly factions. AI will still not accept vassalage or confederacy when their only other option is extinction. Long term allies are like needy ex-girlfriends that will randomly break up with you then a few turns later are burning up your phone to talk. 
Overall it does what Total War does best, combining a turn based over-world with real time tactical battles. It makes fairly good use of the source material. Zooming in on battles shows great detail, good sound, and quite a bit of dialog. Spells and monsters look fantastic, although it can be hard to take time to stop and smell the blood soaked roses in the heat  of battle. 
As someone with a massive amount of time playing the first game, this one being more like a DLC bundle or remaster of the first is a net positive. Being that the TW series tend to be expensive and rarely on sale, the value for money is open to argument. Since it's so close to the first game, just play that until you can score this one on sale. It's worth the upgrade from the first game, but not full retail price worth.
